title: Yum's 3Q Profit Pressured by Investment in Grubhub
text:
By Micah Maidenberg

Yum Brands Inc. (YUM) said profit fell 44% in the third quarter as the company recorded an charge related to its investment in Grubhub Inc. (GRUB).

Yum said it recorded a $60 million pre-tax investment expense related to the change in fair value of its investment in Grubhub. That sliced 15 cents off of its earnings per share.

Grubhub shares dropped 43% Tuesday as it warned of rising competition among delivery services.

Yum, the Louisville-based owner of restaurant chains KFC, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut, reported quarterly net income fell to $255 million, or 81 cents a share, from $454 million, or $1.40 a share, last year.

General and administrative expenses increased 2%, while costs covering franchise advertising and services jumped 13%.

Yum reported global same-store sales, or sales from locations for at least a year, rose 3% in the quarter.

Total revenue slipped 4% from the year earlier, to $1.34 billion, the company said, in line with expectations from analysts.

Same-store sales increased 3% in the KFC business and 4% at Taco Bell, Yum said. Pizza Hut's had flat same-store sales.
